Range-Spread Targets Detection in Unknown Doppler Shift via Semi-Definite Programming

Mai P. T. Nguyen, Iickho Song, ,
Seungwon Lee , and Seokho Yoon, M. P. T. Nguyen, I. Song, and S. Lee are with the School of Electrical Engineering, Korean Advanced Institute of Science and Technology, Daejeon 34141, Korea (huongmainguyen12@gmail.com, i.song@ieee.org, kkori21@gmail.com).S. Yoon is with the College of Information and Communication Engineering, Sungkyunkwan University, Suwon 16419, Korea (syoon@skku.edu).
Abstract

Based on the technique of generalized likelihood ratio test, we address detection schemes for Doppler-shifted range-spread targets in Gaussian noise. First, a detection scheme is derived by solving the maximization associated with the estimation of unknown Doppler frequency with semi-definite programming. To lower the computational complexity of the detector, we then consider a simplification of the detector by adopting maximization over a relaxed space. Both of the proposed detectors are shown to have constant false alarm rate via numerical or theoretical analysis. The detection performance of the proposed detector based on the semi-definite programming is shown to be almost the same as that of the conventional detector designed for known Doppler frequency.

Index Terms:
Doppler frequency, generalized likelihood ratio test, range-spread target, semi-definite programming, reduced space.

I Introduction

In classifying problems of signal detection, we may employ types of signal and noise as a criterion. The types of signal include known deterministic, unknown deterministic, and random signals, and those of noise encompass Gaussian and non-Gaussian noise [1]. Regarding noise, although a non-Gaussian model better represents experimental data and is used in some cases of practical interest [2], the Gaussian model is employed more commonly due to its validity proved by the central limit theorem and mathematical tractability.

In the meantime, while the known deterministic and random signal models arise in a variety of communication problems, the model of deterministic signals with some unknown parameters is commonly found in problems of radar detection [1]. The unknown parameters in problems of radar detection are considered as deterministic quantities or realizations of random variables of known probability density functions (pdf). When the unknown parameters are considered as realizations of random variables, a detector is derived based normally on Bayesian approach. On the other hand, the generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT) is employed when the unknown parameters are considered as deterministic quantities, in which case the unknown parameters are replaced by their maximum likelihood estimates (MLE) [1], [3].

Among radar detection problems, the detection of range-spread targets with an array of antennas in noise has been addressed in a number of studies including [4]–[10], where the target return is assumed to be known up to a multiplication factor of the steering vector in the cases of non-Gaussian [4], [8], and [10] and Gaussian noise environment [5]-[7], [9]. Specifically, in [5] assuming the availability of the signal-free data, called secondary data, the estimation of the noise covariance matrix is employed in the detection, while a modified GLRT has been proposed in [6] without assuming the availability of secondary data. In [7], detection problem of range-spread targets has been addressed in the case of combined thermal noise and external interference, in which the covariance matrix of noise has the form of an identity matrix plus an unknown positive semi-definite matrix.

The detection schemes considered in [4]–[10] might suffer from a performance loss when the knowledge about the steering vector is imperfect as in the case of mismatched steering vector. To reduce such a detection loss when only the range of steering vector is available, the detection problem has been addressed in several studies [11], [12] under the range models of a linear subspace or a cone class. In essence, the subspace detectors, performing the detection by computing the energy of the measurement in the signal subspace [13] based on linear subspace models, have been considered in [13]–[20]. In the meantime, detectors based on cone class models have been considered in e.g., [21]–[25]: In most cases of the detectors under the cone class models, the likelihood ratios are obtained from numerical methods, and consequently, it is not easy to explain and investigate the detection nature and performance.

In this paper, we consider the problem of detecting range-spread targets in a more general case in which the range of steering vector is unknown, a special case of which is the case of unknown velocity of the target. Adopting an approach similar to that in [30], where the detection of a point-like target is considered, we first derive a GLRT based detection scheme for range-spread targets using a semi-definite programming. A simplified detection scheme is then obtained, which possesses an explicit form of the likelihood ratio and thus incurs less computational complexity. Both of the proposed detectors are shown to not only have the constant false alarm rates (CFAR) but also provide detection probabilities comparable to that of the conventional detector derived with known Doppler frequency.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the problem formulation and describes details in the derivation of the proposed detectors. Performance analysis and comparison of the detectors discussed in Section III. Section IV concludes this paper.

II Problem Formulation and Proposed Detector

Consider the problem of detecting the presence of a range-spread target, where the potential target is modelled by an unknown range profile (RP) and experiences a motion of unknown velocity relative to the radar. For the detection, reflection from a sequence of N𝑁N identical coherent pulses of duty cycle TDsubscript𝑇𝐷T_{D} with pulse repetition interval TR≫TDmuch-greater-thansubscript𝑇𝑅subscript𝑇𝐷T_{R}\gg T_{D} is sampled. We assume that the reflection of the extended target, in case a potential target appears, is completely contained in the first L𝐿L range bins, whose data is referred to as the primary data. The remaining data, called the secondary data, occupies the remaining K𝐾K range bins and is composed only of noise (by ”noise” we mean radar clutter plus thermal noise). This scenario includes the special case of L= 1𝐿1L\thinspace=\thinspace 1 (i.e., target is a point scatterer) solved in [26].

II-A Detector based on Semi-Definite Problem

When 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} is unknown, the maximization in (14) can be solved by searching over 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p}, which unfortunately is not quite feasible in practice. We thus change (14) into an equivalent problem for which efficient algorithms can be employed.

Noting that 𝒑=[1,exp⁡(j​θ),…,exp⁡{j​(N−1)​θ}]T𝒑superscript1𝑗𝜃…𝑗𝑁1𝜃𝑇\boldsymbol{p}=\left[1,\exp(j\theta),\ldots,\exp\{j(N-1)\theta\}\right]^{T}, where θ=2​π​fD​TR∈[0,2​π)𝜃2𝜋subscript𝑓𝐷subscript𝑇𝑅02𝜋\theta=2\pi f_{D}T_{R}\in[0,2\pi) is the Doppler phase, let us first rewrite the maximization in (14) as

It is easy to see that x0=tr⁡(𝑺−1​𝒁​𝑿−1​𝒁H​𝑺−1)subscript𝑥0trsuperscript𝑺1𝒁superscript𝑿1superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1x_{0}=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}\boldsymbol{X}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\right) and y0=tr⁡(𝑺−1)subscript𝑦0trsuperscript𝑺1y_{0}=\operatorname{tr}\left(\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\right) are real since 𝑺−1​𝒁​𝑿−1​𝒁H​𝑺−1superscript𝑺1𝒁superscript𝑿1superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}\boldsymbol{X}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} and 𝑺−1superscript𝑺1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} are Hermitian and that the constraint f​(θ,t)⩾0𝑓𝜃𝑡0f(\theta,t)\geqslant 0 is derived from, and therefore equivalent to, t−κ​(𝒑)​𝒑H​𝑺−1​𝒁​𝑿−1​𝒁H​𝑺−1​𝒑⩾0𝑡𝜅𝒑superscript𝒑𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒁superscript𝑿1superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒑0t-\kappa\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\boldsymbol{p}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}\boldsymbol{X}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{p}\geqslant 0.

Now, observe that if f​(θ,t)⩾0​over​θ∈[0,2​π)𝑓𝜃𝑡0over𝜃02𝜋f(\theta,t)\geqslant 0\thinspace\text{over}\thinspace\theta\in[0,2\pi) then t⩾t†𝑡superscript𝑡†t\geqslant t^{\dagger} and vice versa. In other words, the set {t:t⩾t†}conditional-set𝑡𝑡superscript𝑡†\left\{t:t\geqslant t^{\dagger}\right\} of t𝑡t is the same as the set {t:f​(θ,t)⩾0,θ∈[0,2​π)}conditional-set𝑡formulae-sequence𝑓𝜃𝑡0𝜃02𝜋\left\{t:f(\theta,t)\geqslant 0,\thinspace\right.\linebreak\left.\theta\in[0,2\pi)\right\} of t𝑡t. Hence, the solution to the problem (17) is the minimum among the values of t𝑡t making f​(θ,t)𝑓𝜃𝑡f(\theta,t) non-negative over [0,2​π)02𝜋[0,2\pi): To find the minimum, we apply the following theorem, modified from a theorem in [28].

Theorem 1.

The function f​(θ,t)𝑓𝜃𝑡f(\theta,t) is non-negative over [0,2​π)02𝜋[0,2\pi) if and only if there exists a matrix 𝐕∈ℍN×N𝐕superscriptℍ𝑁𝑁\boldsymbol{V}\in\mathbb{H}^{N\times N} such that

t​𝒚−𝒙=𝑾H​diag⁡(𝑾​𝑽​𝑾H).𝑡𝒚𝒙superscript𝑾𝐻diag𝑾𝑽superscript𝑾𝐻t\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{W}^{H}\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{V}\boldsymbol{W}^{H}\right). (21)

Here, ℍN×Nsuperscriptℍ𝑁𝑁\mathbb{H}^{N\times N} denotes the set of N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N non-negative definite Hermitian matrices, 𝐲=[y0,y1,…,yN−1]T𝐲superscriptsubscript𝑦0subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑁1𝑇\boldsymbol{y}=\left[y_{0},y_{1},\ldots,y_{N-1}\right]^{T}, 𝐱=[x0,x1,…,xN−1]T𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑥0subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑁1𝑇\boldsymbol{x}=\left[x_{0},x_{1},\ldots,x_{N-1}\right]^{T}, diag⁡(⋅)diag⋅\operatorname{diag}{\left(\cdot\right)} denotes the N×1𝑁1N\times 1 vector formed with the diagonal elements, and

𝑾=[𝒘0,𝒘1,…,𝒘N−1]𝑾subscript𝒘0subscript𝒘1…subscript𝒘𝑁1\boldsymbol{W}\thinspace=\thinspace\left[\boldsymbol{w}_{0},\boldsymbol{w}_{1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{w}_{N-1}\right] (22)

is an N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N matrix, where 𝐰i=[1,ωM,i,…,ωM,iN−1]Tsubscript𝐰𝑖superscript1subscript𝜔𝑀𝑖…superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑀𝑖𝑁1𝑇\boldsymbol{w}_{i}=\left[1,\omega_{M,i},\ldots,\omega_{M,i}^{N-1}\right]^{T} with ωM,i=exp⁡(−j​2​π​iM)subscript𝜔𝑀𝑖𝑗2𝜋𝑖𝑀\omega_{M,i}=\exp\left(-j\dfrac{2\pi i}{M}\right) for a number M⩾2​N−1𝑀2𝑁1M\geqslant 2N-1 and i=0,1,…,N−1𝑖01…𝑁1i=0,1,\ldots,N-1.

Applying Theorem 1, the minimization (17) can finally be recast as

minimizets.tt​𝒚−𝒙=𝑾H​diag⁡(𝑾​𝑽​𝑾H),𝑽∈ℍN×N.minimize𝑡s.t𝑡𝒚𝒙superscript𝑾𝐻diag𝑾𝑽superscript𝑾𝐻missing-subexpression𝑽superscriptℍ𝑁𝑁\begin{array}[]{ll}{\text{minimize}}&t\\ \text{s.t}&t\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{W}^{H}\operatorname{diag}\left(\boldsymbol{W}\boldsymbol{V}\boldsymbol{W}^{H}\right),\\ &\boldsymbol{V}\in\mathbb{H}^{N\times N}.\end{array} (23)

Since the minimization problem in (23) is a semi-definite problem (SDP), a type of convex optimization problem [28], it can be solved efficiently by various well-known methods such as the interior-point, first-order, and bundle methods [29].

The resulting detector, which will be called the SDP detector, eventually assumes the likelihood ratio test

tC​≷H0H1G2,subscript𝑡𝐶superscriptsubscriptgreater-than-or-less-thansubscript𝐻0subscript𝐻1subscript𝐺2t_{C}\mathop{\gtrless}_{H_{\mathit{0}}}^{H_{\mathit{1}}}G_{2}, (24)

where tCsubscript𝑡𝐶t_{C} is the solution of (23) obtained by, for example, the interior-point method.

Theoretically, the performance of the detector (24) would be the same as that of (13). On the other hand, the performance of (13) will in practice depend on the resolution of the searching grid of θ𝜃\theta (or equivalently, the unknown Doppler frequency) while the detector (24) is less dependent on the searching grid: In addition, various efficient algorithms can be employed in solving (24) as mentioned above. In passing, let us mention that the study in [30] also applied the result in [28] for the detection of point-like targets in correlated Gaussian noise under unknown direction of arrival.

II-B Detector based on Maximization in the Reduced Space

The processing time to obtain the likelihood ratio tCsubscript𝑡𝐶t_{C} from (23) via a semi-definite program increases with the number of range bins (that is, with the range resolution of the radar), as it will be shown later in the numerical results. Another drawback of the likelihood ratio tCsubscript𝑡𝐶t_{C} is that it has no explicit form, not allowing an insight into the performance characteristics of a detector such as the CFAR property.

We now derive a detector that can be obtained when the search over 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} is replaced with the search over all N×1𝑁1N\times 1 complex vectors. With this relaxation, we can move a few steps further in simplifying, and explicitly showing, the structure of the detector. Of course, since we do not exploit a priori knowledge about 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p}, the simplification is achieved at the expense of some performance loss, and therefore, the detector will have a lower detection probability than its original version.

Firstly, as 𝑺−1superscript𝑺1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} is Hermitian, we have 𝑺−1=𝑼S−1H​𝚲S−1​𝑼S−1superscript𝑺1superscriptsubscript𝑼superscript𝑆1𝐻subscript𝚲superscript𝑆1subscript𝑼superscript𝑆1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\thinspace=\thinspace\boldsymbol{U}_{S^{-1}}^{H}\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{S^{-1}}\boldsymbol{U}_{S^{-1}} from the unitary similarity [31], where 𝑼S−1subscript𝑼superscript𝑆1\boldsymbol{U}_{S^{-1}} is an N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N unitary matrix such that 𝑼S−1H=𝑼S−1−1superscriptsubscript𝑼superscript𝑆1𝐻superscriptsubscript𝑼superscript𝑆11\boldsymbol{U}_{S^{-1}}^{H}=\boldsymbol{U}_{S^{-1}}^{-1} and 𝚲S−1subscript𝚲superscript𝑆1\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{S^{-1}} is the N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N diagonal matrix composed of the eigenvalues {λi}i=1Nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑁𝑖1\left\{\lambda_{i}\right\}^{N}_{i=1} of 𝑺−1superscript𝑺1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}. Note that the diagonal elements {λi}i=1Nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜆𝑖𝑁𝑖1\left\{\lambda_{i}\right\}^{N}_{i=1} of 𝚲S−1subscript𝚲superscript𝑆1\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{S^{-1}} are all positive with probability one since 𝑺−1superscript𝑺1\boldsymbol{S}^{-1} is positive definite with probability one. where G~2subscript~𝐺2\tilde{G}_{2} is the threshold. In Appendix B, it is shown that the MRS detector (31) possesses the CFAR property.

III Numerical Results

In this section, we assess and compare the performance, the probabilities of detection and false alarm, of the proposed detectors (24) and (31) with that of the conventional detector

𝒑H​𝑺−1​𝒁​𝑿−1​𝒁H​𝑺−1​𝒑𝒑H​𝑺−1​𝒑​≷H0H1G~3superscript𝒑𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒁superscript𝑿1superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒑superscript𝒑𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒑superscriptsubscriptgreater-than-or-less-thansubscript𝐻0subscript𝐻1subscript~𝐺3\frac{\boldsymbol{p}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}\boldsymbol{X}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{p}}{\boldsymbol{p}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{p}}\thinspace\mathop{\gtrless}_{H_{\mathit{0}}}^{H_{\mathit{1}}}\thinspace\tilde{G}_{3} (32)

derived when 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} is known, where G~3subscript~𝐺3\tilde{G}_{3} is a threshold. The detector represented by (32) will be called the one-step GLRT (OS-GLRT) [5]. In short, (32) is an ideal detector, of which the performance represents the bound of other detectors designed for unknown 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p}.

III-A Parameters

The detection performance of three detectors was assessed with N=8𝑁8N=8 identical coherent pulses transmitted with the pulse repetition interval TR=40subscript𝑇𝑅40T_{R}=40 μ𝜇\mus and Doppler frequency fD=10subscript𝑓𝐷10f_{D}=10 kHz (which corresponds to a velocity of 150150150 m/s for a wavelength of λ=3𝜆3\lambda=3 cm). The number L𝐿L of range cells in the primary data is lower bounded by the ratio of the range extent of a target to the range resolution of the radar and it could be of several hundreds [5]. To alleviate the computational burden, we chose L=8,12,16𝐿81216L=8,12,16, and 202020 with the energy distribution among scatterers as shown in Table I. The size of the secondary data is chosen as K=16​N=128𝐾16𝑁128K=16N=128 so that the matrix 𝑺𝑺\boldsymbol{S} of the secondary data is non-singular. For use in (22), we have chosen M=2​N−1=15𝑀2𝑁115M=2N-1=15. Finally, we use the software CVX (http://cvxr.com/) to solve the semi-definite problem (23) on a computer equipped with a 3.4 GHz Intel processor.

III-B Simulation Results and Discussion

The performance of the SDP and MRS detectors are assessed for the detection of steady and fluctuating targets embedded in Gaussian noise of various correlation degrees in comparison with the OS-GLRT detector. In addition, the complexities of the three detectors are considered in terms of the average processing time. Since it is not plausible to derive explicit forms of the false alarm and detection probabilities, we resort to Monte Carlo trials, in which we set the false alarm rate at 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. Since the MRS and OS-GLRT detectors possess CFAR property as shown in Appendix B and in [5], respectively, the thresholds of the MRS and OS-GLRT detectors are determined once. The threshold of the SDP detector are, on the other hand, determined for each noise covariance.

III-B1 Threshold of the SDP detector

We first investigate if the SDP detector also has a CFAR property. Here, correlated noise vectors with covariance matrix

𝑪=σn2​[1ρ…ρN−1ρ1…ρN−2⋮⋮⋱⋮ρN−1ρN−2…1]𝑪superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2matrix1𝜌…superscript𝜌𝑁1𝜌1…superscript𝜌𝑁2⋮⋮⋱⋮superscript𝜌𝑁1superscript𝜌𝑁2…1\boldsymbol{C}\thinspace=\thinspace\sigma_{n}^{2}\begin{bmatrix}1&\rho&\ldots&\rho^{N-1}\\ \rho&1&\ldots&\rho^{N-2}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \rho^{N-1}&\rho^{N-2}&\ldots&1\end{bmatrix} (33)

are employed, where σn2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\sigma_{n}^{2} and ρ𝜌\rho denote the average noise power at one range cell and the one-lag correlation coefficient, respectively.

Fig. 1 shows the false alarm rates Pf​asubscript𝑃𝑓𝑎P_{fa} of the SDP detector as a function of threshold at various values of ρ𝜌\rho when σn2=1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛21\sigma_{n}^{2}=1. It is observed from the figure that the threshold for a specific value of Pf​asubscript𝑃𝑓𝑎P_{fa} does not depend on ρ𝜌\rho. We believe this observation is a natural consequence since the likelihood ratio of the SDP detector is a close approximation to that of the OS-GLRT detector, which possesses a CFAR property.

III-B2 Detection performance with steady targets

We now evaluate the detection performance of proposed detectors when the RP of a potential target remains constant during the observation time. The performances are investigated at velocities v=−100𝑣100v=-100, 120120120, 150150150, and 180180180 m/s corresponding to Doppler frequencies fD=−6.67subscript𝑓𝐷6.67f_{D}=-6.67, 888, 101010, and 121212 KHz, respectively. In the evaluation, we assume L=8𝐿8L=8 and ρ=0.4𝜌0.4\rho=0.4. The detection probabilities Pdsubscript𝑃𝑑P_{d} are shown in Fig. 2 as a function of the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) defined as

SNR=‖𝒑‖2​∑i=1L|αi|2L​N​σn2.SNRsuperscriptnorm𝒑2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖2𝐿𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\mbox{SNR}=\frac{\|\boldsymbol{p}\|^{2}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{L}|\alpha_{i}|^{2}}{LN\sigma_{n}^{2}}. (34)

It is observed from Fig. 2 that the SDP detector achieves nearly the same performance as the OS-GLRT detector and outperforms the MRS detector. For example, the SDP detector provides a gain of around 1.41.41.4 dB over the MRS detector for all the values of fDsubscript𝑓𝐷f_{D}. To explain, we recall that information about the form of a target’s return 𝒑=[1,exp⁡(j​2​π​fD​TR),…,exp⁡{j​2​π​fD​(N−1)​TR}]T𝒑superscript1𝑗2𝜋subscript𝑓𝐷subscript𝑇𝑅…𝑗2𝜋subscript𝑓𝐷𝑁1subscript𝑇𝑅𝑇\boldsymbol{p}=\left[1,\exp\left(j2\pi f_{D}T_{R}\right),\ldots,\exp\left\{j2\pi f_{D}(N-1)T_{R}\right\}\right]^{T} is exploited in the SDP detector; yet to the MRS detector such information is not exploited.

Assume L=8𝐿8L=8, we next assess detection probabilties in noise with various ρ𝜌\rho: 00, 0.40.40.4, and 0.90.90.9. It is shown from Fig. 3 that with proposed detectors, a higher value of ρ𝜌\rho associates to a better detection performance. For example, at SNR=−10SNR10\mbox{SNR}=-10 dB, with ρ=0.9𝜌0.9\rho=0.9 proposed detectors yield Pd=1subscript𝑃𝑑1P_{d}=1; yet with ρ=0.4𝜌0.4\rho=0.4 the SDP detector yields Pd≈0.3subscript𝑃𝑑0.3P_{d}\approx 0.3 and the MRS detector yields Pd≈0.1subscript𝑃𝑑0.1P_{d}\approx 0.1. When ρ𝜌\rho approaches 111, for example, ρ=0.999𝜌0.999\rho=0.999 (for brevity simulation result are not presented), all detectors achieve Pd=1subscript𝑃𝑑1P_{d}=1 at SNR=−25SNR25\mbox{SNR}=-25 dB. This observation is intuitively reasonable since a higher value of ρ𝜌\rho implies more similarity between noise samples, i.e., more imformation about noise, which possibly leads to a better detection performance.

III-B3 Detection performance with fluctuating targets

Let us next address detection performances of proposed detectors when a potential target’s RP fluctuates. Firstly, we describe how we generate a fluctuating RP. We note that target’s radar cross section (RCS) representing the total energy reflected from the target also fluctuates with a fluctuating RP target. In addition, such fluctuating RCS is well described by the Swerling models [36]. Based on [35], we derive the relationship between a target’s RCS, denoted by σ𝜎\sigma, and its RP

σ∝12​∑j=1L|αj|2.proportional-to𝜎12superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑗2\sigma\thinspace\propto\thinspace\frac{1}{2}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{L}|\alpha_{j}|^{2}. (35)

We now assume that, for simplicity, all main scatterers on the target follow a same fluctuating pattern. With this assumption and existing models of fluctuating σ𝜎\sigma, the generation of a fluctuating RP is straightforward. We employ, in the evaluation, Swerling II and IV models, and we use L=8𝐿8L=8. Note that Swerling II and IV models are chi squared distributions of 222 and 444 degrees of freedom, respectively. Therefore, a Swerling II variable exhibits larger covariance, i.e. more fluctuation, than a Swerling IV variable at a same expectation, In the sequel, we refer a target with Swerling II or IV RCS as a Swerling II or IV target, respectively. The averaged SNR is defined as

SNRa​v=E​[‖𝒑‖2​∑i=1L|αi|2]L​N​σn2∝2​σ¯​‖𝒑‖2L​N​σn2,subscriptSNR𝑎𝑣𝐸delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒑2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑖2𝐿𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2proportional-to2¯𝜎superscriptnorm𝒑2𝐿𝑁superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑛2\mbox{SNR}_{av}=\frac{E\left[\|\boldsymbol{p}\|^{2}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{L}|\alpha_{i}|^{2}\right]}{LN\sigma_{n}^{2}}\propto\frac{2\bar{\sigma}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|^{2}}{LN\sigma_{n}^{2}}, (36)

where a​v𝑎𝑣av stands for ‘averaged’ and σ¯¯𝜎\bar{\sigma} the average of a target’s RCS.

In Figs. 4 and 5, we show detection probabilities Pdsubscript𝑃𝑑P_{d} of proposed detectors, in comparison with the OS-GLRT detector, as functions of the averaged SNR. These figures highlight observations identical to those derived from Figs 2 and 3.

The order of performance in terms of target’s type are steady, Swerling IV, and Swerling II. Lower probabilities in the detection of a fluctuating target, compared to a steady target, is expected since fluctuation in a target’s RP is not considered in the design stage of the three detectors. Similarly, since a Swerling II target’s return exhibits more fluctuation than that of a Swerling IV target, detection probability with a Swerling II target is lower than that with a Swerling IV target.

III-B4 Detection with incorrect information about Doppler frequency

In Fig. 6, we compare the detection performance of the proposed detectors with that of the OS-GLRT detector when information about Doppler frequency is incorrect. In the evaluation, the pre-assumed Doppler frequency is 101010 KHz, yet the actual value is 121212 KHz. We use L=8𝐿8L=8, ρ=0.4𝜌0.4\rho=0.4, and a steady RP. We observe that the SDP and the MRS detectors outperform the OS-GLRT detector with performance gaps, for example at SNR = −1010-10 dB, of about 666 and 555 dB, respectively. This observation is easily anticipated since the operations of the SDP and the MRS detectors do not require Doppler frequency information; however, the OS-GLRT detector requires an exact information about Doppler frequency.

III-B5 Complexity of proposed detectors

Finally, we consider the complexity of proposed detectors in terms of average time consumption (in second). Here, we assess time consumption with different RP’s length L=8𝐿8L=8, 121212, 161616, and 202020. For each detector, computational time is averaged over 100010001000 repetitions to make results reliable.

It is shown in Table II, as easily anticipated, that the SDP detector assumes much more processing time, which is in an order of 10−1superscript10110^{-1}, than the MRS and the OS-GLRT detectors, whose processing time are in the order of 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. Besides the computation shared by all detectors, the MRS detector computes the maximum eigenvalue of 𝒁H​𝑺−1​𝒁superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒁\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}, which exhibits a little more computation than the matrix multiplications 𝒑H​𝑺−1​𝒁​𝑿−1​𝒁H​𝑺−1​𝒑superscript𝒑𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒁superscript𝑿1superscript𝒁𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}\boldsymbol{X}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{p} and 𝒑H​𝑺−1​𝒑superscript𝒑𝐻superscript𝑺1𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{H}\boldsymbol{S}^{-1}\boldsymbol{p} implemented in the OS-GLRT detector. For the SDP detector, to implement the semi-definite programming (23) exhibits even much more computation.

We notice that the SDP detector’s computational complexity is unsuitable for a radar scan mode. Yet, though possessing fast implementation, the MRS detector may miss a target due to lower detection performance, for which a measure is to increase transmitted power.

IV Conclusion

We have proposed GLRT-based detectors for a range-spread target of unknown Doppler frequency embedded in Gaussian noise. Regarding the SDP detector, we resort to a semi-definite programming to solve the optimization problem associated to the MLE of unknown Doppler frequency. To reduce the implementation complexity of the SDP detector, we then address a suboptimal detector by solving the above optimization over a relaxed space. Performance of proposed detectors have been assessed, in comparison with the conventional detector derived with known Doppler frequency, in noise of various correlation degrees and with steady and fluctuating targets. It is observed that the detection gap between the SDP detector and the conventional detector is negligible. In addition, performance of the MRS detector could be considered as a lower bound for GLRT-based detectors when no information about a potential target is available. Both proposed detectors have been proved, theoretically or numerically, to possess CFAR.

The main drawback of this paper is the lack of closed forms for detection and false alarm probabilities of the proposed detectors, which is for a future research. Also, we plan to consider the detection problem under a more generalized noise model, the spherically invariant random process.

Appendix B Proof of the CFAR property of the LRT (31)

We will prove the CFAR property of the LRT (31) by showing that the distribution of the maximum eigenvalue dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} of 𝚼𝚼\boldsymbol{\Upsilon} under the null hypothesis does not depend on the noise covariance matrix 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C}.

Let us first decompose 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C} as

𝑪=𝑼CH​𝚲C​𝑼C,𝑪superscriptsubscript𝑼𝐶𝐻subscript𝚲𝐶subscript𝑼𝐶\boldsymbol{C}=\boldsymbol{U}_{C}^{H}\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C}\boldsymbol{U}_{C}, (46)

where 𝑼Csubscript𝑼𝐶\boldsymbol{U}_{C} is an N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N unitary matrix such that 𝑼C−1=𝑼CHsuperscriptsubscript𝑼𝐶1superscriptsubscript𝑼𝐶𝐻\boldsymbol{U}_{C}^{-1}=\boldsymbol{U}_{C}^{H} and 𝚲Csubscript𝚲𝐶\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C} is the N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N diagonal matrix composed of the eigenvalues of 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C}. Next, define

𝒁~=𝑸−1​𝒁bold-~𝒁superscript𝑸1𝒁\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}\thinspace=\thinspace\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z} (47)

and

𝒁~S=𝑸−1​𝒁S,subscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆superscript𝑸1subscript𝒁𝑆\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}\thinspace=\thinspace\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{Z}_{S}, (48)

where

𝑸=𝑼CH​𝚲C1/2​𝑼C𝑸superscriptsubscript𝑼𝐶𝐻superscriptsubscript𝚲𝐶12subscript𝑼𝐶\boldsymbol{Q}\thinspace=\thinspace\boldsymbol{U}_{C}^{H}\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C}^{1/2}\boldsymbol{U}_{C} (49)

with 𝚲C1/2superscriptsubscript𝚲𝐶12\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C}^{1/2} denoting the N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N diagonal matrix of the square roots of the diagonal elements of 𝚲Csubscript𝚲𝐶\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C}: Note that the diagonal elements of 𝚲Csubscript𝚲𝐶\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_{C} are positive since 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C} is positive definite. Then, under the null hypothesis, we have 𝒁~=[𝑸−1​𝒏1,𝑸−1​𝒏2,…,𝑸−1​𝒏L]bold-~𝒁superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏1superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏2…superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝐿\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}=\left[\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{1},\thinspace\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{2},\ldots,\thinspace\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{L}\right] and 𝒁~S=[𝑸−1​𝒏L+1,𝑸−1​𝒏L+2,…,𝑸−1​𝒏L+K]subscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝐿1superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝐿2…superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝐿𝐾\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}=\left[\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{L+1},\right.\linebreak\left.\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{L+2},\ldots,\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{L+K}\right]: Thus, for any column of 𝒁~bold-~𝒁\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}} and 𝒁~Ssubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}, we have

E​[(𝑸−1​𝒏j)​(𝑸−1​𝒏j)H]𝐸delimited-[]superscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝑗superscriptsuperscript𝑸1subscript𝒏𝑗𝐻\displaystyle E\left[\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{j}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{n}_{j}\right)^{H}\right] =\displaystyle= 𝑸−1​E​[𝒏j​𝒏jH]​(𝑸−1)Hsuperscript𝑸1𝐸delimited-[]subscript𝒏𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒏𝑗𝐻superscriptsuperscript𝑸1𝐻\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}E\left[\boldsymbol{n}_{j}\boldsymbol{n}_{j}^{H}\right]\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\right)^{H} (50)
=\displaystyle= 𝑸−1​𝑪​(𝑸−1)Hsuperscript𝑸1𝑪superscriptsuperscript𝑸1𝐻\displaystyle\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\boldsymbol{C}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}^{-1}\right)^{H}
=\displaystyle= 𝑰N,subscript𝑰𝑁\displaystyle\boldsymbol{I}_{N},

which implies that the distributions of 𝒁~bold-~𝒁\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}} and 𝒁~Ssubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S} do not depend on 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C}.

Finally, since 𝚼𝚼\boldsymbol{\Upsilon} can be expressed as

𝚼𝚼\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\Upsilon} =\displaystyle= 𝒁~H​𝑸H​(𝑸​𝒁~S​𝒁~SH​𝑸H)−1​𝑸​𝒁~superscriptbold-~𝒁𝐻superscript𝑸𝐻superscript𝑸subscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆𝐻superscript𝑸𝐻1𝑸bold-~𝒁\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}^{H}\boldsymbol{Q}^{H}\left(\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}^{H}\boldsymbol{Q}^{H}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}} (51)
=\displaystyle= 𝒁~H​(𝒁~S​𝒁~SH)−1​𝒁~superscriptbold-~𝒁𝐻superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆𝐻1bold-~𝒁\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}^{H}\left(\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}^{H}\right)^{-1}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}

from 𝑺=𝒁S​𝒁SH=𝑸​𝒁~S​𝒁~SH​𝑸H𝑺subscript𝒁𝑆superscriptsubscript𝒁𝑆𝐻𝑸subscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆superscriptsubscriptbold-~𝒁𝑆𝐻superscript𝑸𝐻\boldsymbol{S}=\boldsymbol{Z}_{S}\boldsymbol{Z}_{S}^{H}=\boldsymbol{Q}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}\boldsymbol{\tilde{Z}}_{S}^{H}\boldsymbol{Q}^{H}, it is clear that, under the null hypothesis, the distribution of the maximum eigenvalue dmaxsubscript𝑑d_{\max} of 𝚼𝚼\boldsymbol{\Upsilon} does not depend on the noise covariance matrix 𝑪𝑪\boldsymbol{C}.
